articles.headline: Women Lead Parade of Victories to Help Democrats Win House
articles.snippet: Women ran in historic numbers, breaking rules and upending conventional political wisdom.
articles.abstract: Women ran in historic numbers, breaking rules and upending conventional political wisdom.
articles.lead_paragraph: They marched, they ran, and on Election Day, they won.
articles.byline: By Susan Chira and Kate Zernike

articles.headline: Losers in Amazon Sweepstakes Aren’t Ready to Throw In the Towel
articles.snippet: There were tax breaks. Ads on Seattle buses. Amazon latte art. And, finally, fading hope that the e-commerce giant would be coming to town.
articles.abstract: There were tax breaks. Ads on Seattle buses. Amazon latte art. And, finally, fading hope that the e-commerce giant would be coming to town.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Chicago offered $2 billion in tax breaks. North Carolina wrapped buses in Seattle with a pitch for Raleigh. A Philadelphia coffee chain printed the Amazon logo into the foam of its lattes.

articles.headline: Visions of a Tech Hub? Landing Amazon Is Just a Start
articles.snippet: How the company and local officials flesh out plans for the new corporate presence will be crucial to the economic lift it produces.
articles.abstract: How the company and local officials flesh out plans for the new corporate presence will be crucial to the economic lift it produces.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Amazon announced plans to build a second headquarters somewhere in North America, it set off a competition for a sort of new-economy golden ticket, a chance for one city to become, almost overnight, a magnet for the high-paying jobs and entrepreneurial spark that are hallmarks of urban success in the 21st century.

articles.headline: Democrats Capture Control of House; G.O.P. Holds Senate
articles.snippet: Republicans were on track to add to their Senate majority, defeating Democratic senators and holding onto Texas by beating back Representative Beto O’Rourke
articles.abstract: Republicans were on track to add to their Senate majority, defeating Democratic senators and holding onto Texas by beating back Representative Beto O’Rourke
articles.lead_paragraph: Democrats harnessed voter fury toward President Trump to win control of the House and capture pivotal governorships Tuesday night as liberals and moderates banded together to deliver a forceful rebuke of Mr. Trump, even as Republicans held on to their Senate majority by claiming a handful of conservative-leaning seats.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Democrats Oust Walker in Wisconsin and Kobach in Kansas but Fall Short in Florida and Ohio
articles.snippet: Over all, the Democrats reclaimed six governor’s seats from the G.O.P., including pickups in Michigan and Illinois.
articles.abstract: Over all, the Democrats reclaimed six governor’s seats from the G.O.P., including pickups in Michigan and Illinois.
articles.lead_paragraph: Democrats wrested control of governorships from Republicans in seven states on Tuesday including Wisconsin, where they ousted Scott Walker after eight tumultuous years as the state’s chief executive, and Kansas, a surprise victory in a longtime Republican stronghold.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Sydney Ember and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: Two Years After Trump’s Victory, Voters Erect an Impediment to His Power
articles.snippet: In handing Democrats the House majority, voters in urban and suburban districts ended one-party rule in Washington and decided to curb President Trump’s power.
articles.abstract: In handing Democrats the House majority, voters in urban and suburban districts ended one-party rule in Washington and decided to curb President Trump’s power.
articles.lead_paragraph: The vaunted blue wave that Democrats had hoped for failed to fully materialize on Tuesday night, but the days of one-party control in Washington are now over. President Trump’s strength in rural areas kept the Senate in Republican control, but voters in urban and suburban districts across the country sent the White House a clear message: They want a check on the president.

articles.headline: A Partisan War Awaits Trump. That Just Might Suit Him.
articles.snippet: Combative by nature, happier in a fight, the president may now have to choose between escalating the conflict that has torn Washington apart in recent years and trying to reach across the aisle.
articles.abstract: Combative by nature, happier in a fight, the president may now have to choose between escalating the conflict that has torn Washington apart in recent years and trying to reach across the aisle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump will wake up on Wednesday morning to a radically new political environment as he confronts the prospect of a two-year partisan war with a Democratic-run House armed with subpoena power and empowered to block his legislative agenda.

articles.headline: Why the Google Walkout Was a Watershed Moment in Tech
articles.snippet: Outsiders have little leverage to force the industry to change. The companies’ own workers are another matter.
articles.abstract: Outsiders have little leverage to force the industry to change. The companies’ own workers are another matter.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a few hours last Thursday, just about everything at Google ground to a halt. At 11 a.m. local time in a movement that rolled like an angry and jubilant tide around the globe, more than 20,000 employees walked out to protest the company’s long history of protecting executives accused of sexual harassment.

articles.headline: Trump Vows ‘Warlike Posture’ if Democrats Investigate Him
articles.snippet: The president said he hoped to cut bipartisan deals but vowed to retaliate if the new Democratic-controlled House examines his finances and political dealings.
articles.abstract: The president said he hoped to cut bipartisan deals but vowed to retaliate if the new Democratic-controlled House examines his finances and political dealings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump threatened on Wednesday to adopt a “warlike posture” against Democrats if they use their newly won control of the House to investigate his financial and political dealings, drawing a line at the start of a new era of divided government.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear
